text: we're on the third day now of the
European and American bombing campaign
against Colonel Gaddafi's forces that
was designed first to constrain his air
power but then it appears to free up the
rebels to take on Colonel Qaddafi
they've moved very quickly after just
one day on from attacking his air strike
capability to going after his troops on
the ground and his supply line so now
we're waiting to see what are the rebels
going to do the word from the east where
my colleague Korean fahim is reporting
is that they have so far been unable to
move their line forward beyond the city
of edge deb√≠a where they've been
fighting before the airstrikes began
they've consolidated their hold on
Benghazi more or less although there's
still some reports of a little bit of
strife around Benghazi but they haven't
been able to burst through the Qaddafi
lines even with the help of Western air
support here in Tripoli the big news is
that one bomb fell last night on Colonel
Gaddafi's compound and hit some kind of
an administration building which the
Allied forces characterized as a command
and control facility the Qaddafi
government is characterizing this as
another attempt on his life there was no
evidence of casualties around the
bombing since the airstrikes happened
they've been warning us that the
population of Tripoli will be very very
hostile to us as Europeans and Americans
and may even be armed because Colonel
Qaddafi has talked about arming
civilians to fight off the Western
powers however in my experience frankly
even in mobs of Qaddafi supporters
waving green flags and green bandanas I
felt no personal hostility whatsoever
people have been very cordial to me and
I haven't seen any increase at all in
the number of guns around Tripoli there
were already a lot of guns around
Tripoli but I haven't seen any increase
any you know you don't see civilians
running on weapons and when we run
errands go out to the store people are
just as happy to see us as they were a
week ago in other good news our four
colleagues of the four near Times
journalist who were captured in the east
and had been imprisoned in one form
another for six days were released today
into the custody of the Turkish
ambassador who drove them to the border
with Tunisia and by now God willing
they're on
